TI Assessing Human Disease Phenotype Similarity Based on Ontology
SO 2016 IEEE RIVF INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON COMPUTING & COMMUNICATION
   TECHNOLOGIES, RESEARCH, INNOVATION, AND VISION FOR THE FUTURE (RIVF)
LA English
DT Proceedings Paper
CT IEEE RIVF International Conference on Computing & Communication
   Technologies, Research, Innovation, and Vision for the Future (RIVF)
CY NOV 07-09, 2016
CL Thuyloi Univ, Hanoi, VIETNAM
SP IEEE, IEEE Vietnam Sect, IEEE Commun Soc, IEEE Computat Intelligence Soc
HO Thuyloi Univ
DE human phenotype ontology; disease phenotype similarity; semantic
   similarity measure; between-term similarity; between-entity similarity
ID SEMANTIC SIMILARITY; GENE ONTOLOGY; FUNCTIONAL SIMILARITY; HETEROGENEOUS
   NETWORK; RANDOM-WALK; PREDICTION; EXPRESSION; SEARCHES; COMMON
AB Phenotypical similarity between diseases is an important factor in biomedical research since it has been used in many disease-related studies. More specifically, this information improves prediction performance of methods proposed for identifying disease-associated cellular components. In addition, this is also useful to figure out relationship among diseases to explain disease co-morbidity phenomenon. However, calculating and assessing the similarity among disease phenotypes is still an open question. Indeed, most studies have utilized an out-of-date disease phenotype similarity database constructed from OMIM records, which is also considered as a "gold standard" one, while only a few of studies have calculated this similarity based on human phenotype ontology. Considering that many methods have been defined to measure the similarity between two ontology-annotated entities, assessing which one is the best is crucial. In this study, we calculate the similarity for a set of 9,221,365 pairs of disease phenotypes using a number of ontology-based semantic similarity measures and assess them by correlating them with the "gold standard" one. Simulation results showed that, for both types of correlation (i.e., Pearson and Spearman correlations), the largest correlation coefficient is 0.58 for both pairwise between-entity similarity methods. Interestingly, these results are consistent with previous studies which assess similarity between genes based on gene ontology.
C1 [Le, Duc-Hau] Water Resources Univ, Sch Comp Sci & Engn, Hanoi, Vietnam.
   [Pham, Ba-Su; Dao, Anh-Minh] FPT Univ, Hanoi Educ & Training Zone, Hoa Lac High Tech Pk,Km29 Thang Long Highway, Hanoi, Vietnam.
RP Le, DH (reprint author), Water Resources Univ, Sch Comp Sci & Engn, Hanoi, Vietnam.

TI Detection of Lesion Region in Skin Images by Moment of Patch
SO 2016 IEEE RIVF INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON COMPUTING & COMMUNICATION
   TECHNOLOGIES, RESEARCH, INNOVATION, AND VISION FOR THE FUTURE (RIVF)
LA English
DT Proceedings Paper
CT IEEE RIVF International Conference on Computing & Communication
   Technologies, Research, Innovation, and Vision for the Future (RIVF)
CY NOV 07-09, 2016
CL Thuyloi Univ, Hanoi, VIETNAM
SP IEEE, IEEE Vietnam Sect, IEEE Commun Soc, IEEE Computat Intelligence Soc
HO Thuyloi Univ
DE moment of patches; dermoscopic images; diagnostic imaging
ID PATTERN-RECOGNITION; INVARIANTS; REGISTRATION
AB Image-based estimation of skin lesions is efficient sub-field of medical imaging. The objective of task is to achieve more proper assessment of treatment effects. A significant group of skin lesion detection methods makes use of spatial relationships in order to deliver features for image region. Recently, a few study advances have been made in this particular group of area-based methods. This paper presents a new method that uses advantage of specific priori knowledge of lesion region detected by moment of patch. Since the lesion region determination basis is color values and surrounding pixels area moment of difference of two image patches predicts homologous changes as evaluation of similarity of the patches. We use an adequate algorithm to detect skin region with application of geometric moments. Our main contribution are (i) the exercising of area moment to compose a database of skin lesion templates, and (ii) a lesion region detection scheme that estimates the image patches resemblance based on moment of patches so that lesion region can be discovered. The capability of the method is demonstrated by analyzing images of a skin lesion benchmark using the templates extracted from other independent database.
C1 [Dao Nam Anh] Elect Power Univ, Dept Informat Technol, Hanoi, Vietnam.
RP Anh, DN (reprint author), Elect Power Univ, Dept Informat Technol, Hanoi, Vietnam.
OI Nam Anh, Dao/0000-0002-0536-8686

   BELKASIM SO, 1991, PATTERN RECOGN, V24, P1117, DOI 10.1016/0031-3203(91)90140-Z
   Cavalcanti PG, 2011, COMPUT MED IMAG GRAP, V35, P481, DOI 10.1016/j.compmedimag.2011.02.007

TI Detection of New Drug Indications from Electronic Medical Records
SO 2016 IEEE RIVF INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON COMPUTING & COMMUNICATION
   TECHNOLOGIES, RESEARCH, INNOVATION, AND VISION FOR THE FUTURE (RIVF)
LA English
DT Proceedings Paper
CT IEEE RIVF International Conference on Computing & Communication
   Technologies, Research, Innovation, and Vision for the Future (RIVF)
CY NOV 07-09, 2016
CL Thuyloi Univ, Hanoi, VIETNAM
SP IEEE, IEEE Vietnam Sect, IEEE Commun Soc, IEEE Computat Intelligence Soc
HO Thuyloi Univ
AB Drug repositioning - detection of new uses of existing drugs - is an emerging trend in pharmaceutical industry. It essentially is a multiple aspect process of analyzing large-scale heterogeneous data for exploiting advantage of off-targets of the existing drugs. Three kinds of omics, phenomic and drug data are often integrated and used to study drug repositioning. The recent prevalence of electronic medical records (EMRs) makes it become an extremely significant resource of phenomic data for drug repositioning in the post-market stage. However, there is still no generic process and method to this end. This work aims to establish such a process and method. The paper addresses the solution of the first two problems in this complex process.
C1 [Tran-Thai Dang; Ouankhamchan, Phetnidda; Tu-Bao Ho] Japan Adv Inst Sci & Technol, 1-1 Asahidai, Nomi, Ishikawa 9231292, Japan.

TI Real-Time Brainwave-Controlled Interface Using P300 Component in EEG
   Signal Processing
SO 2016 IEEE RIVF INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON COMPUTING & COMMUNICATION
   TECHNOLOGIES, RESEARCH, INNOVATION, AND VISION FOR THE FUTURE (RIVF)
LA English
DT Proceedings Paper
CT IEEE RIVF International Conference on Computing & Communication
   Technologies, Research, Innovation, and Vision for the Future (RIVF)
CY NOV 07-09, 2016
CL Thuyloi Univ, Hanoi, VIETNAM
SP IEEE, IEEE Vietnam Sect, IEEE Commun Soc, IEEE Computat Intelligence Soc
HO Thuyloi Univ
DE EEG signal processing; P300 speller; brain computer interface;
   brainwave-controlled applications
ID COMPUTER-INTERFACE; RECOGNITION; POTENTIALS; PARADIGM
AB Electroencephalography (EEG) is an emerging field of digital signal processing. EEG is electrical signals which are recorded by the sensors attached on the human scalp to detect human's brain activities along the scalp. EEG signal processing has been a technically challenging problem for researchers due to its extremely noisy nature compared to other different kinds of digital data such as voice or image. However, EEG signals also create promising research areas and applications for the human being. This paper aims at designing a brain-controlled interface using P300 component in EEG signal processing. The EEG signal's P300 component is an event related potential (ERP) component elicited by the human's brain in the process of decision making. We use the oddball paradigm presented by the P300-Speller to create the brain-computer interface for the subject to express their intention of thinking via the computer screen. The device used to record the brain signal is the Emotiv EPOC headset. We exploit the Bayesian linear discriminant analysis (BLDA) to classify the P300 signals. We conduct the experiments to help people express their thought in 1-out-of-4-choice interfaces in real time. The choices, which are presented on the computer screen, could be anything from letters to images or specific symbols. The experimental results reveal the acceptable accuracy of correct classification to be 80 percent and the best bitrate of over 10 bits per minute.
C1 [Ha Hoang Kha; Vo Anh Kha] Ho Chi Minh City Univ Technol, VNU HCM, Ho Chi Minh, Vietnam.
RP Kha, HH (reprint author), Ho Chi Minh City Univ Technol, VNU HCM, Ho Chi Minh, Vietnam.

TI System Pharmacology: Application of Network Theory in Predicting
   Potential Adverse Drug Reaction Based on Gene Expression Data
SO 2016 IEEE RIVF INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON COMPUTING & COMMUNICATION
   TECHNOLOGIES, RESEARCH, INNOVATION, AND VISION FOR THE FUTURE (RIVF)
LA English
DT Proceedings Paper
CT IEEE RIVF International Conference on Computing & Communication
   Technologies, Research, Innovation, and Vision for the Future (RIVF)
CY NOV 07-09, 2016
CL Thuyloi Univ, Hanoi, VIETNAM
SP IEEE, IEEE Vietnam Sect, IEEE Commun Soc, IEEE Computat Intelligence Soc
HO Thuyloi Univ
DE Adverse drug reactions; Side effects; Biological network;
   Protein-protein interaction; Systems biology; Systems pharmacology;
   Network centrality; Connectivity Map; CMap; Dioxin; Breast cancer; 2, 3,
   7, 8-tetrachlorodi-benzo-p-dioxin; TCDD; dioxin; Network theory; Gene
   expression profile
ID KOLMOGOROV-SMIRNOV TEST; BREAST-CANCER; DIOXIN; IDENTIFICATION;
   SIMILARITY; SIGNATURES; CYTOSCAPE; STITCH; RISK
AB In drug development process, adverse drug reaction (ADR) is one of the biggest challenges to evaluate the drug safety for passing to the market. Genomic expression data following in vitro drug treatments and thus have become widely used in ADR identification and prediction. In this research, we develop the prediction method by using system pharmacology-based study. We performed the proteomic, small molecular compounds - protein interaction and ADR data based on Connectivity Map database. A major protein-drug-side effect (PDS) network and a protein-drug (PD) network were obtained and analyzed by followed network centrality study, which allows for selection of side effects that are defined as central nodes. From the result, the top ranking of novel side effects was identified. In a case study, we established prediction models for 2, 3,7, 8-tetra-chlorodibenzo-p-dioxin (TCDD) in breast cancer treatment adverse events. In conclusion, the network-based approach provided the relationship between protein targets network and side effects based on the gene expression profiles and can predict the potential side effects for new a combinatory drug in the drug development process.
C1 [Duy Pham; Bao-Khanh Le; Le, Ly] Int Univ, Dept Biotechnol, Hcmc, Vietnam.

TI Domain-Driven Design Patterns: A Metadata-Based Approach
SO 2016 IEEE RIVF INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON COMPUTING & COMMUNICATION
   TECHNOLOGIES, RESEARCH, INNOVATION, AND VISION FOR THE FUTURE (RIVF)
LA English
DT Proceedings Paper
CT IEEE RIVF International Conference on Computing & Communication
   Technologies, Research, Innovation, and Vision for the Future (RIVF)
CY NOV 07-09, 2016
CL Thuyloi Univ, Hanoi, VIETNAM
SP IEEE, IEEE Vietnam Sect, IEEE Commun Soc, IEEE Computat Intelligence Soc
HO Thuyloi Univ
AB Design pattern is the most common form of object oriented software reuse. In object oriented domain driven design, a number of high-level patterns have been identified and applied for over a decade. However, no concrete design patterns for domain modelling in this method have been published in the literature. A primary challenge in defining these design patterns is how to express their form in a way that eases their application to a specific domain that uses a specific object oriented programming platfonn. In this work, we propose a set of concrete design patterns, whose fonn is expressed in a domain class modelling language (DCML). DCML is based on UML and uses implementation-aware meta-attributes to define design metadata. We extend this language with new meta-attributes to support the proposed design patterns. Further, we discuss how domain-specific examples of these patterns are translated to physical class models for automatically generating software prototypes.
C1 [Due Minh Le] Univ Hanoi, Dept Software Engn, Hanoi, Vietnam.
   [Due-Hanh Dang; Viet-Ha Nguyen] VNU Univ Engn & Technol, Dept Software Engn, Hanoi, Vietnam.
RP Le, DM (reprint author), Univ Hanoi, Dept Software Engn, Hanoi, Vietnam.

TI A Novel Online Bayes Classifier
SO 2016 INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON DIGITAL IMAGE COMPUTING: TECHNIQUES AND
   APPLICATIONS (DICTA)
LA English
DT Proceedings Paper
CT International Conference on Digital Image Computing - Techniques and
   Applications (DICTA)
CY NOV 30-DEC 02, 2016
CL Gold Coast, AUSTRALIA
SP Australian Govt, Dept Defence, Defence Sci & Technol Grp, IAPR, Canon Informat Syst Res Australia, IEEE, Griffith Univ, APRS
DE online learning; variational inference; multivariate Gaussian
   distribution; Bayes classifier; non-linear classifier
ID ALGORITHMS; PERCEPTRON
AB We present VIGO, a novel online Bayesian classifier for both binary or multiclass problems. In our model, variational inference for multivariate Gaussian distribution technique is exploited to approximate the class conditional probability density functions of data in an online manner. Besides being a conservative learner with a low number of updates compared with many other popular algorithms, VIGO algorithm can be updated in a minibatch of an arbitrary size which makes it robust with noise data. Experiments over a large number of UCI datasets demonstrate the advantage of VIGO with many state-of-the-art methods presented in LIBOL - a prevalent library for online learning algorithms.
C1 [Thi Thu Thuy Nguyen; Tien Thanh Nguyen; Liew, Alan Wee-Chung] Griffith Univ, Sch Informat & Commun Technol, Nathan, Qld, Australia.
   [Xuan Cuong Pham] Water Resource Univ, Fac Comp Sci & Engn, Hanoi, Vietnam.

TI DrbCF: A differentiated ratio-based approach to job scheduling in cloud
   federation
SO PROCEEDINGS OF 2016 10TH INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON COMPLEX,
   INTELLIGENT, AND SOFTWARE INTENSIVE SYSTEMS (CISIS)
LA English
DT Proceedings Paper
CT 10th International Conference on Complex, Intelligent, and Software
   Intensive Systems (CISIS)
CY JUL 06-08, 2016
CL Fukuoka Inst Technol, Fukuoka, JAPAN
SP Univ Politecnica Catalunya, SCAT
HO Fukuoka Inst Technol
AB The utilization and flexibility of using resource embrace each organization builds its own private cloud. Cloud Federation is a recent paradigm that helps deal with both physical resources under-utilization and resource limitation in their local infrastructure. Due to the management separation, we are interested in self-sufficiency approach in discovering and matchmaking to establish the federation with other clouds. We leverage event-based design helps communicate over sites to enable negotiate scheduling between among providers. We propose decentralized broker supporting differentiated ratio-base job scheduling (DrbCF) to manage send/receive workload. Our evaluation shows the ability to accept new small capacity member and improve overall federation throughput with the differentiated rate approximately 14-16%. DrbCF is a useful tool supporting the differentiated capacity sites as well as the dynamic of interconnect structure under cloud circumstance.
C1 [Phuong-Duy Nguyen; Nam Thoai] HCMC Univ Technol, Ho Chi Minh, Vietnam.

TI A Performance Analysis in The One-Way Full Duplex Relaying Network
SO PROCEEDINGS OF 2016 19TH INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON NETWORK-BASED
   INFORMATION SYSTEMS (NBIS)
SE International Conference on Network-Based Information Systems
LA English
DT Proceedings Paper
CT 19th International Conference on Network-Based Information Systems
   (NBiS)
CY SEP 07-09, 2016
CL Tech Univ Ostrava, Ostrava, CZECH REPUBLIC
SP Fukuoka Inst Technol, Tech Univ Catalunya
HO Tech Univ Ostrava
ID INFORMATION
AB Nowadays, the using of redundant energy in the environment and protecting the earth opposing the global climate change is emerged as a urgent measure drawing the majority of people in the world. Among of them, the energy harvesting protocol is a highlight attracting the concerning of many projects as well as the study of many scientists specially in wireless communication field. This paper mentions the energy harvesting structure of the full duplex relaying systems. By employing the time switching based relaying (TSR) protocol and Amplify-and-Forward (AF) model, we advance the closed-form expression of the outage probability and then calculate the optimal throughput. An essential result can be found observably that the noise factor, the time fraction, the target ratio as well as the position of relay in TSR affect on the optimal throughput. After at all, the numerical results imply an effective relaying plan in full duplex cooperation systems.
C1 [Kieu, Tam Nguyen; Voznak, Miroslav] VSB Tech Univ Ostrava, 17 Listopadu 15-2172, Ostrava 70833, Czech Republic.
